comment._content: Excellent to know, thank you! So that would imply that if he was fighting in WWI, that he made it home... (hopefully)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content: And that cap badge looks like that of the Royal Irish Regiment (18th Foot), which had Kilkenny in its recruiting catchment. Interestingly, elements of the RIR were among the first British troops to attack the rebels in Dublin during the 1916 Rising. Following on S.W. Harris and the RIR - this site www.achart.ca/articles/hibernian/last_roll_call.htm mentions that a Maj. S.W. Harris, MBE, of the RIR was the last adjutant of the Royal Hibernian Military School in Phoenix Park. This image from the same site www.achart.ca/articles/hibernian/images/hibcol_sm.jpg may in fact show Maj. Harris at the rear of a color party that deposited the colors of the RHMS in Windsor in 1924.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/woesinger] WOW! I cannot thank you enough for this. No time this a.m. to read all of the information on the Royal Hibernian Military School, but look forward to getting back to it later on! Do you think it really is S.W. in the photo?? That would be amazing... Thanks again!

comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content:
Not a bother. Was just a bit of idle Google-powered curiosity. 

Just a guess on the photo. If S.W. was the adjutant of the RHMS, it stands to reason he might be involved in standing down the colors, and there's some resemblance between the (blurry) figure in that photo and the man in this photo (both appear to have splendid mustaches).

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content:
Thanks to my resourceful friend in Dublin, John O'Grady for looking him up:

1911 census of Ireland
He was Lieutenant Samuel Wallace Harris, Quartermaster, The Royal Irish Regiment.
Recorded in the 1911 census at, Danville, Kilkenny.
 
He was 38 years old and had been born in Tasmania.
His wife Isabel was aged 41, and had been born in England
They were married for 9 years, and had 3 children.
Vera Mildred, aged 8, born in England.
John Russell Harris, aged 4, born in England. [his birth registered in Apr-Jun 1907, at Tenterden, Kent, England]
Vere Wallace Harris, aged 2, born in India [born on 11 April 1909, at Kasauli, Bengal, India. The mother is named as Isabel, but her surname was not noted.
 
Samuel Wallace Harris was recorded in the 1901 census of England & Wales at Windsor, Berkshire.
 
What he was doing in Danville, Kilkenny, is something else.
The house is a large building, with 10 rooms and 7 out-buildings.
It might possibly have been a small farm.
Danville is about 1 mile SE of Kilkenny city, so it can be presumed that Harris was based in a barracks close to the town centre

comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content:
Should have thought of the census! :)

And to corroborate the census record, he's wearing the shoulder insignia of a first lieutenant in the photo.
